Please remove this video or amend it.  I agree with many of the other comments.  The installation of the 3A switch is dangerous for two reasons.  Many, if not most power tools require far more current than 3A.  Severe overheating could cause a fire.  Also, the cord was never intended to be cut.  Extension cords get pulled, yanked, tripped over, etc.  When the outer sheathing was removed, it removed much of the structural integrity.  A hard pull could cause one of the hot leads to pull lose, or even sever the neutral or ground, causing a short.  A much better option for switching would be a 15A grounded single-port power adapter with an On/Off switch.

Thank you for showing the "roadie wrap" or folding cable wrap. I've worked as a roadie and audio engineer for years and have tried to teach this to all my support people. It's tough to teach but once they get it, they get it. One thing to keep in mind, however, is you must throw the cable out holding the end of the cable where you started your wrap. If you throw out from the opposite end, you'll put an overhead knot for every loop you made into your cable. Not fun. Plan your throw. I almost always throw from the "talent" end to my audio or power source. Hence when I wrap, i start by unplugging then walking to the talent side and wrapping the cable in from the talent side. Make sense? This works great with round cables. Flat cables like a flat extension cord, however, are better served with a slip knot wrap aka electrician's wrap. Thank you for showing all these tips!

I like the idea of an inline switch on the cord, but be cautioned that you need to match the switch rating to that of the extension cord.  Your 3 amp switch can and most likely will overheat when you use the cord for something with a larger power draw than 3 amps.  Consumers routinely exceed the amp rating of extension cords, usually by using too small of cord for too large of a load.  I was lucky enough to avoid a fire when the plug on a 100' 16 gauge cord melted on me while using a worm drive circular saw.  I should have been using at least a 12 gauge cord, according to the charts I now have.

Careful with that switch. When you install a 3A switch you reduce the amperage rating of the entire cord to 3A.  This would be fine for a device with a known current draw as you would know if it could handle it or not. The drawback with extension cords is that you never know what will be attached to the other end. It could be a powerstrip with 5 drills all plugged in.  The standard amperage rating on 120V home wiring is 15A. I would have tried to find a switch that could handle at least 10A, possibly even one with a breaker in it.

Make sure the switch can take the maximum current of that extension cord. Plugs in the US don't contain fuses so its up to your breaker to disconnect the supply. Generally the wire inside your wall is thicker than the extension cord and can take more current. And your breaker is appropriate for that wire in the wall... not your extension cord. So if you somehow manage to draw too much current though that extension cord... it will most likely survive but if that switch is under-rated then it will be your point of failure and cause a fire. Just be careful!
